title: Parametric ( Ultimachine 1Kg ) spool hub bearing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A bearing hub for my 1Kg spool from ultimachine. STL spool ID = 51.87mm, SCAD provided to change as needed. Uses 608 bearing by default I'm using it with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22759 as a bracket Update: Changed scad to be clearer on variable names. Added 1 layer skin under hole.

Make two of these, add two bearings, place on M8 rod on either side of your spool.
By default, the hole is closed by a .25mm layer to provide bridge support.  Drill it out or set it to 0mm in the scad if you want to just make an uglier unsupported hole/bridge.  That's actually how I printed mine, and it worked ok.
If the inside of the bearing hole is tight you can run a 7/8ths inch (or 22-23 mm, if you have such a thing) spade drill bit into the hole to ream the edges.

title: Dungeon In My Pocket Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A new adventure By Julian “Legend” Jimenez Using the ZimP v1.5 game system By Jeremiah Lee © 2007-2008
Your brother, the evil wizard snuck up behind you and knocked you out. When you woke up, you found yourself stuck in his stinky old dungeon. It turns out that he found out it was you who snitched to mom about him trying to destroy the kingdom again.
Oh yeah, he poisoned you too. You have 3 hours before the poison kills you. Now you have to get out and give him a good old-fashioned noogie and beating from big brother and get the antidote. First you have to find the key and the exit to the dungeon. Then you have to find your brother. You must do all this before the clock strikes midnight.

You will need your miniatures to play this game. I have made a means of joining the tiles together.

author: sigterm9

print_settings.Notes:: A 0.4mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer heights would prove more accurate then my 0.6mm nozzle at 0.4mm layer heights. Enjoy.

description.text:
2/1018 I have since made a switch to the cr10 extruder to test it out on a variety of extruders and I have to say that it is working GREAT!! I can't wait to try flexibles with it, also just setup a cyclops with it and going to be testing that out very soon..

2/6/18 It has came to my attention that a flat area will need to be grinned into the round shaft as I have been seeing slipping of the extruder gear. A simple metal file or a dremal tool should be fine to use.

2/2/18 Ok it's confirmed that this works! (My printer is printing with it right now)... Do note: My extruder steps_per_mm needed to be changed by almost 4x my original amount. Nonetheless, this extruder setup seems to be very accurate.

2/1/18 I have actually ended up using my original aluminum MK8 extruder mounted to the frame for this instead of a printed extruder as it functioned better and is easy to attach. Why replace something if it worked fine before? This will make for less printing and hopefully people could use this system by simply attaching their current extruder. Also, I noticed a little bit of slipping so i made a small washer to increase the spring tension some. So far it works. I'm about to start a long print to try it out.

As I use the design more I can refine it and make improvements.

NOTE: It's best to get a shaft that is 5mmx50mm for the large gear.

BOM:

1 5mmx50mm Shaft https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MTKNWZB/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1 60 Tooth Gear 5mm hole https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074V7HVHB/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1 16 Tooth Gear https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XH3BZBC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1 Drive Gear
3 3mmx25mm Screws
5 3mmx12mm Screws for motor and mount
4 3mm Nuts
1 Nema 17-Mounting Extruder of your choice.
2 4mm wide x 5mm ID x 13mm OD bearings
1 200-2gt belt

Printer:

custom corexy

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

When printing these parts I used 50% infill, but you could probably get away with 20%. I printed my version at 0.4mm layers heights using a 0.6mm nozzle. I'll probably re-print everything later on using 0.2 layer heights. Good luck and let me know if you have any questions.

The area on the bottom where the bearing inserts might need support, depending on your printer. If so, a 1/2" drill bit in the size works great to clean it up and make it flush. To clean the M5 screw holes I found a 13/64" drill bit works great, and a 1/8" drill bit works well to open up the M3 holes.

A 0.4mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer heights would prove more accurate then my 0.6mm nozzle at 0.4mm layer heights. Enjoy.

What is it?

This is a replacement drain plug for the floor of my Polaris General. I lost one and thought I'd have a shot at designing a new one.

How do I use it?

This is half the plug. Print two of these halves and glue them together. I put alignment pin holes on them that should fit 5mm dowel pins. I used those pins that hold up shelves in Ikea style shelving units. You can get them anywhere. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072LW7T7M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

If you print it from ABS you can solvent weld them. PLA prints will need glue. It almost doesn't matter what glue you use since there is no stress on the joint when in use. In fact the drain hole holds the halves together.

What does it fit?

It fit perfect in my 2017 Polaris General 4 seater. This might fit other Polaris machines, I have no way to check. If you find it fits other machines I'd love to hear from you.

It should be at least as watertight as the original which are not all that water tight. These may be better since they cover more than the original plug.

It's worth printing an extra for your glovebox. It would be no fun to loose a plug on the trail and have to ride with wet feet.

Where are the design files?

The design was done in onShape and it's public so you can tweak it for your own use. Please leave a comment if you find a design improvement or use it as is.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7cf48b5689f65ea58ac175d9/w/ae11ffd40433a16df054ba0b/e/766206a922526269df3a83cd

Enjoy.
Wanted a means of making my spools, of various sizes, spin on their center. These allowed each spool to center on an M8 rod.

Have you spent hours searching for something large, unwieldy, and unbelievably stylish for your Nerf Hera? Well look no further! Style is one of our chief concerns at SlightlyOddGuy Industries, and we believe the SlightlyOdd ACOG scope is just for you!

The SlightlyOdd ACOG scope boasts a large, easy-to-see-through aperture for any who wants no doubt that the enemy is in their sights. With a delicate targeting reticle showing three whole delineation marks compensating for bullet drop, that very scenario might actually happen, given the right circumstances! The SlightlyOdd ACOG scope also comes with moveable adjustment knobs, completely nonfunctional, but full of satisfying aesthetic feel! We take pride in our designs, and we're confident that this product will meet all your needs and more!

Enjoying your ACOG? Check out our other Nerf-compatible attachments and items!

title: glock 17 stock or buffertube or arm brace adapter

description.text:
This should fit on a full framed glock 17 or KSC glock 17 for airsoft. currently it is just a frame without a buffer tube. my intent on this is to make a buffer tube adapter so it will be a non-NFA item. buffer tubes dont make pistols SBR's at least in the USA. The 'Spike' should fit into a glock fine, and the upper brace should snap fit onto the beaver tail. fit a pin on the grip as with all glock stocks should have.

Added a rail to the rear so a tube or accessories can slide on.

description.text:
OttoDIY-MXR


This is a version tested of OttoDIY PLUS and I am currently make some changes in order to add more capabilities, Led Matrix 8x8, ISD1820 Voice recorder, color sensor and RFID interaction, the principal changes was the dimension of Otto's body (70mmx70mmx70mm).

To chek the original project go to: https://github.com/OttoDIY/PLUS
and to download these project visit: https://github.com/MexRoboTics/OttoDIY-MXR

Printer:

MiniFab3D v1.2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%
I design this model in Solidworks Education software

Description and Configuration

Description:

Here are modified libraries and sketch tested for Otto DIY robot, the capabilties are: Led Matrix Mouth, Bluetooth connection, two action mode buttons,and some more in development...

Compatibility with Zowi App or Otto DIY App

Changes

In order to add more sensors and use the next Led Matrix:
<!-- .element height="20%" width="20%" -->
I have made size modification to Otto parts.

Bill of Materials

  • Arduino Nano V3.0;
  • Arduino Nano Shield I/O Extension Board Expansion
  • Mini usb cable.
  • HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor.
  • Mini servo MG90 9g x4 (each one should come with 2 pointed screws and one small screw also arm keys to attach legs and feet).
  • passive Buzzer 12mm 5V
  • Female to Female breadboard connectors cable 10cm x24.
  • 4 AA Battery case *
  • 1.5V AA batteries x4.*
  • Phillips screwdriver (important magnetized)
  • micro Switch 8x8mm
  • Touch sensors x3 *
  • Sound sensor module
  • Bluetooth module HC-05 or HC06 or BLE
  • 3D printed head
  • 3D printed body
  • 3D printed leg x2
  • 3D printed right foot

  • 3D printed left foot

    • you could replace them wit a LIPO battery and push buttons

Give life to Otto-MXR (Programming)

  • Download and Install Arduino IDE: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
  • If you have a clone board download the next driver in order to recognize the board: http://www.wch.cn/download/CH341SER_EXE.html for Windows User, or http://www.wch.cn/download/CH341SER_MAC_ZIP.html for MAC Users
  • Copy all libraries to C:\Program Files (x86)\Arduino\libraries (or wherever your library folder is installed)

  • Before you programming otto, sure that the module Bluetooth is correctly configured (Baud-rate for programming module is 9600 or 19200 or 38400, depends on a module):

    • For Module HC-05: (38400?) 115200
      1. Upload the sketch HC05_BT_config.ino to your Nano first, then disconnect Nano from USB
      2. Now connect BT to Nano as shown in diagram but do not connect VCC
      3. Plug in the USB to Nano and then connect VCC so BT enters AT mode. LED on BT should start to blink slower, about once every 2 seconds. (If this doesn't work, try holding the button on BT module while connecting VCC).
      4. Open serial monitor in IDE, set baud-rate to 9600 and line ending to Both NL & CR.
      5. Type AT then press enter; (if everything is right, BT should respond with OK and then enter following commands:
        • AT+NAME=Zowi "setting the name"
        • AT+PSWD=1234 "pairing password"
        • AT+UART=115200,1,0 "baud rate"
        • AT+POLAR=1,0 "enabling STATE pin to be used as reset for programming arduino over BT"
    • For HC-06: (9600?) 115200
    • For HC-06 BT module things are a little simpler because module is always in AT command mode when not connected to anything. But the downside is that HC-06 module cannot be used to upload sketches to Arduino because it doesn't have reset. For configuring the module:
      1. upload the sketch HC06_BT_config.ino to your Nano first, then disconnect Nano from USB
      2. Now connect BT to Nano as follow
    • Tx -> Rx
    • Rx -> Tx
    • VCC -> 5V
    • GND -> GND
      1. Power on your Nano and after about 10-15 seconds everything should be finished and your BT should be configured (LED13 should start blinking).

  • The BT code(OTTO_BT_easy.ino and OTTO_BT.ino) has 115200 baud-rate so BT module must match that speed to be able to communicate with Arduino Nano via serial interface(UART).

  • Now open the sketch OTTO_BT_Matrix_Led.ino
  • Check the pins connection section, if you have different pins associated, change this connections in the file Otto.h
  • Disconnect the VCC pin of Bluetooth module before upload the code
  • Make sure in tools you have "Board: Arduino Nano" "Processor ATmega328" and your Otto is connected to the corresponding port
  • Upload the code and connect the VCC pin of Bluetooth module
  • Open the Zowi or Otto App and enjoy!

Share it in Otto builder Facebook group https://www.facebook.com/ottodiy/groups/

description.text:
These holders are for supporting the Rode M5 mics at a 110 degree angle to each other within the Rode Blimp 2 windscreen. A standard XLR connector will not fit on the back of these mics in this configuration, you have to get creative and fabricate a low profile one like I show in the pictures.

To support the microphone within the rings, use a small zip-tie to fasten #17 size o-rings in a crossed pattern, as shown in the pictures. You can use different size o-rings or elastic too.

If you don't want to use the screws that came with the lyres, they are M3 x 16 mm flanged button head cap screws.

There are two files, one for right facing, and one for left facing.

title: CR10-S E3D Clone Extruder Mount (Large & Small Nozzles)

description.text:
This is a no frills Extruder Mount for an E3D Clone Extruder. The extruder I purchased was advertised under E3D, however it appears to be a bit shorter than the actual E3D Extruders. This is a Remix to fix this problem, unsure if it would work with a normal E3D, but clould likely be tweaked easily to fit.

Has some additional features the last mount was missing, such as an extra bolt on point for the Top Mount, making the extruder more stable, A space for the Hotend Cables to be wired back to the board, and extensions to further stabilize the extruder.

Fits two fans, one 30mm and one 40mm. (I swapped fans from the original extruder mount from the CR10 and wired in the new E3D fan) I recommend Higher Infill to help with airflow.

You are gonna need a few extra M3x20 & A single M3x8 (Roughly) Screws.

PRINTING: Flip over the Bigger Part on its back so the flat part is on the bed, then do a few supports just touching the buildplate to support the fan output. Top Part can be printed either way, but also requires some supports.
Large Nozzle version has the Fan Output sitting 3mm Lower.

This thing is remixed from SmellyUnory's Creality CR-10 SMART V6 mount.
Found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2560599

And if you get a chance check out Vektorz.com

description.text:
This is a demonstration of an open source tool chain to produce an object defined by a formula.

I used the following Octave script to make the stl file:

 clf;
 [x,y,z] = meshgrid (-2:0.05:2, -2:0.05:2, -2:0.05:2);
 kr = -0.5;
 v= (x.^2 + y.^2 + ((z - 1.)*0.5).^2).^kr ...
+ ((x - 0.943).^2 + (y).^2 + ((z + 0.333)*0.5).^2).^kr ...
+ ((x + 0.5).^2 + (y - 0.816).^2 + ((z + 0.333)*0.5).^2).^kr ...
+ ((x + 0.5).^2 + (y + 0.816).^2 + ((z + 0.333)*0.5).^2).^kr;
 v1=v1*600;   
 [f1,v1]=isosurface (x, y, z, v, 4.8);
 axis equal;
 patch("Faces",f1,"Vertices",v1,"facecolor","r");
 #  from http://iso2mesh.sourceforge.net
 #  note that 'savestl' rescales the shape
 savestl(v1,f1,"blob07_octave.stl");

Note that the file is scaled to be quite small, so I rescaled it in Slic3r to make the 40mm version.

A Celtic tree of life pendant. I printed it at .200 resolution out of Hatchbox White PLA at 195C, Sanded it, trimmed the stray stringers that popped up between the knot strands, and painted with acrylic.

(Note: The method I used to paint it was to coat it entirely with black acrylic, then used alcohol and rags to wipe almost all of the acrylic back off. The result left acrylic in the ridges and corners and whatnot, giving it a nice aged look... somewhat like antique carved bone.)

I intend to attach a pendant bail to the piece, at the top center. Should fit nicely there under that top middle branch.

print_settings.Notes:: I used some M3 screws to test (as in the photos) but the idea is to have M3 rods that runs right through with nylock nuts on each end. The door angles are adjustable but you may need to place a small thin silicone washer inside each hinge so they stay where you move them to. So far I've been a bit brutal and simply tightened the screws to hold the doors in position. I may give this a bit more thought for later versions.

description.text: Barn door clip-on for Nikon SB-900 and SB-910 speedlights. Ideal for when you want to use on camera bounce flash and want to ensure that no light hits the subject directly from the actual flash (i.e. use it as a flag). Also great for of camera use to reduce light spill. Doors are individually adjustable to flag or pass light

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Being purposely vague about my settings because it would depend on how you slice it.

I would suggest to make the Flash_Mount as strong as possible as that is what will take the most hammering when this is in use.

The one in the pictures is printed in PLA, 60 bed for the first few layers, and 205 nozzle to make sure layers stick together well.

I printed the actual doors a very low resolution because this as the first print and I just wanted to see if it all comes together and what I would need to change in future versions. All in all it is very usable as is. The Flash_Mount is pretty much the exact same one I use for the grid mount system (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2322639) and it clips on very well to both Nikon SB900 and SB910 speedlights. Depending on your slicer settings this may need very little or (as in my case due to low res settings) a fair bit of cleanup.

I used some M3 screws to test (as in the photos) but the idea is to have M3 rods that runs right through with nylock nuts on each end. The door angles are adjustable but you may need to place a small thin silicone washer inside each hinge so they stay where you move them to. So far I've been a bit brutal and simply tightened the screws to hold the doors in position. I may give this a bit more thought for later versions.

This is an inverted version of the default Donkey Raspberry Pi mounting plate and camera mount. It is inverted so that the electronics are mounted below the plate when installed and the original vehicle body can be installed. It also makes for easy access to the uSD card for easy removal and insertion.

It does use the a feature from the MCAD utility package so you'll want to download and install that. You can get it from here: https://github.com/elmom/MCAD

https://youtu.be/YOHUB8JxVU8

The cap is setup to use 40mm long M4 hardware. I used socket head cap screws for mine.

There's .STL and the better .AMF that CURA accepts as well as versions with and without sensor and with or without a mount for a chain. This fits most standard chains on Thingiverse but I like this one most: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193695 and am listing this as a remix. I have included that chain file.

For part cooling I recommend Mistral 2.1A 4.5 from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121279

For mounting the belt I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2264558

This is 100% Designed from scratch in Solidworks 2016.

Choose your part and print!

  • 18mm Sensor and chain mount
  • 18mm Sensor with no chain mount
  • 12mm Sensor and chain mount
  • 12mm Sensor andno chain mount
  • 8mm Sensor and chain mount
  • 8mm Sensor and no chain mount
  • No sensor with chain mount
  • No sensor, no chain
  • Smaller sensors put it closer to the extruder but tend to have shorter detection distances.

To use this you must be on Skynet/Marlin firmware and make the changes below:

Get the firmware from https://github.com/thijsk/Skynet3d

For the 18mm probe set :

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -28 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

For the 12mm probe set:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -23 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

For the 8mm probe set:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -20 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

And the travel limits are:

// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)

define X_MAX_POS 240
define X_MIN_POS -10
define Y_MAX_POS 230
define Y_MIN_POS -13
define Z_MAX_POS 230
define Z_MIN_POS 0

You also must set

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

See my PDF offsets guide here: https://goo.gl/fJyuiC

It is written for my dual extruder carriages but the Z probe offset still applies here for those using a probe.

Here's a crapCAD schematic of the optocoupler board I made to run the 12v probe completely isolated from the RAMPS board.

Updates:

  • 2/11/18 Changed fillet on fan mount to make it easier to print.

Please like, comment and share! Thank you and enjoy!

description.text:
This is my updated improvements to the Cyborg Beast Hand. I am in NO way trying to take credit for the brilliant design by Jorge Zuniga and his research group at Creighton University. I simply made some updates utilizing elements from other hands and new flexible filament material.

Despite the Cyborg Beast being considered an "outdated design", I find it requested very often by my e-Nable recipients. I think this has a lot to do with the overall look of the hand. Kids like the metallic hardware of the design and embrace the fact that they have a robot hand. I stay in touch with my recipients and have received some valuable design feed back that lead to what I feel are improvements.

To that end I updated the palm to do away with the Velcro attachments and now the design incorporates a screwed in palm mesh that should be made from a flexible filament. This closely follows the design of the Phoenix V2 hands. I also cleaned up the base STL a little and added small brackets over the tendon line grooves to ensure the tendon lines stay within the grooves.

The Gauntlet received the biggest change. I keep receiving feedback from the field that a leather bracer cuff, like the one utilized on the Osprey, is the most comfortable design. With that in mind I modified the gauntlet to be able to accept a leather cuff and two nylon straps to secure the gauntlet in place. Feedback from my recipients has this as a significant improvement over Velcro. Also since I didn't make any changes in how the gauntlet connects to the palm the original gauntlet design will work with the updated palm for those not comfortable making a leather cuff.

I plan on continuing to tinker with this design and update as I make changes.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

Both the palm and especially the new gauntlet design requires supports. I found 13% support density in a grid pattern works well.

Also please refer back to Jorge Zuniga's original Cyborg Beast hand for the rest of the needed parts such as the fingers, phalanges. and tensioner block.
Assembly is largely unchanged from the original Cyborg Beast Hand though any 1st time builder may want to read the assembly instructions for an Osprey hand on how to size and create a leather cuff.
Much of the updates where done either in Blender or Tinkercad depending on what I needed doing.

title: MSE-6 Mouse Droid base plates with holes for magnets

description.text:
A fellow MSE-6 Droid friend has his top greeblies mounted with magnets. I wanted to improve on his design and hide my magnets inside the base plate. I remixed these in Tinkercad and made the holes to allow you to place magnets in the middle/during the print. I highly recommend gluing them in during the print so that they dont get sucked out by some metal on the hotend or fan. I used .2 resolution and paused the print at 2.6mm and 5.0mm, I'm pretty sure.

These are the magnets I used.
1.26"x1/16" for base plate
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B071JC8282/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

1.26"x1/8" for 2x base plate
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MSTKTSF/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I use the opposite on the underside. If it's the 1/8" on top, I use 1/16" under the shell and vice versa.

This is a basic Remote battery terminal lug, you can use this along with 3/8" bolts to relocate a battery charging outlet to the outside of your car / go cart / etc.
This will save time during races as you won't have to open you rhood up, which is usually held in place with pins or what not and many times the battery itself is tucked away and hard to reach with a charging cable set.
Please this on the outside of your cart, and connect it with 4 gauge wire leading back to the terminals of the battery and you'll be able to charge easily.

Use 3/8" Copper bolt for the middle bolt, that will be your terminal. Use regular 3/8 bolts to secure to the outside.

Print in Red for Positive, and black for negative.

author: creativesam

description.text:
I guess this is a 3d printer kit, technically. I made these parts for my printer made out of recycled laser printer parts (Mostly 6mm rods). Everything mounts to wood planks so you can use whatever lengths you recover while recycling easily. Just adjust the bushing print size to fit whatever size of rods you are using.

The X axis parts are probably the most interesting for reuse. The rods are held in parallel and carry a carriage with vgrooves cradling printed bushings in line with the rods. The bushings are held in place with zipties so you can change them out for a different size rod without reprinting the whole x carriage, or use two different sized rods.
I made these parts in openscad while fiddling around with bootstapping a printer from scratch.

title: Zowi DIY build your own robot with Arduino

description.text:
Zowi is a redesign of the Otto DIY PLUS (https://github.com/OttoDIY/PLUS).
With this 3D model, you have room for: bluetooth module, metal gear servo (MG90S), Led matrix mouth, rechargeable battery, light sensor, touch sensor, etc.
And some bonus conveniences: can use remaining screws in servo pack to fix arduino board and power switch.

List of parts:
  1. Arduino Nano ATmega328 + USB Mini Cable
  2. Zowi board x1
  3. HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor(with cable) x1
  4. Mini servo SG90 9g x4 (each one should come with 2 pointed screws and one small screw also arm keys to attach legs and feet).
  5. Switch(with cable) x1
  6. LED Matrix 8x8(with cable) x1
  7. Dual cells battery AA socket x1
  8. Bluetooth module (with cable) x1
  9. Battery 14500 3.7V x2
  10. 3.7V Charge(Dual cells)

And then you only need to 3D print 6 parts in total:

  1. 3D printed head.
  2. 3D printed body.
  3. 3D printed leg x2.
  4. 3D printed right foot.
  5. 3D printed left foot.

1. Download & Install Arduino IDE: https://www.arduino.cc/
  2. Copy all libraries to C:\Users\user\Documents\Arduino\libraries (or wherever your library folder is installed):
  3. Upload to your Arduino Nano for Zowi .
  4. Download Zowi app from google play store to your android phone.
  5. Pair the bluetooth with Zowi.
  6. Open Zowi app, and have fun!!

description.text:
If you purchase a DYS F4 Pro v2, the manufacturer ships a thin spacer to mount on top of your flight controller to keep other electronics like your VTX or RX off of the gyro. I purchased a second one thinking it was the V2 but, it was the V1 which doesn't come with that spacer plate. So, I made one. Two different versions. Second version has a notch in case your vtx and rx has a smart port that prevents your component from laying flat on the spacer.

A half-metre wing-span model of a Waco assault glider, as used by US forces in WWII.

I'd set my students the challenge of designing a glider, in groups, which could be 3d printed and then launched fro a bungee catapult - it was a design and project management exercise rather than a flight challenge, but we encountered a problem which proved quite difficult to overcome.

Printing in PLA, the gliders all came out very heavy, which lead to a very high wing-loading and, as a result, very poor flight performance. Although I tried to improve matters by allowing ever larger wing-spans to try to reduce wing-loading, the majority of the designs the students were coming up with were essentially solid structures, so the wing-loading stayed more or less the same - there proved to be practical limits to how big a wing-span you could go for and achieve a rigid structure without resorting to glue, too...

This is an experiment in creating a frame-structured glider, which can then be covered with heat-shrink film (solafilm or similar). I took inspiration from the designs of Barnes-Wallis to create a geodetic fuselage which could be printed in sections without the need for supports; all of the .stl files will print this way, although some of them not as cleanly as I'd have liked...

My plan was to join all the sections together with small printed pins - the student project required the gliders to be assembled without glue. Unfortunately, the pins didn't print very well (they were too small for the resolution of my printer and tended to break apart when I took them of the build-plate), so I used short lengths of cocktail sticks and...well...glue instead.

I've designed the glider to take micro-servo's in the wings and fuselage to control the flight-surfaces, but never got as far as fitting them before this project fell by the wayside - you can see from the photo's that the ailerons, rudder and elevator are all awaiting fitting - I was just going to use tape as a flexible hinge.

Because this is a bit of a "work in progress", I've included the .dwg for anybody who fancies modifying or improving the design - have fun etc. :)

title: Child Resistant Stove Knob Covers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I originally purchased hinged stove knob covers at a big box store several years ago. Since then I kept going back to the store and buying new ones every few months because the hinges kept breaking and I wanted to keep the stove safe from my kids. At about $20 per set, these were about $5 a piece. After doing some testing, I came to the conclusion that the ones sold at big box store were designed to fail so that you would go buy new ones. Even with mild use, the plastic gets brittle and completely falls apart after just several months, they must be using some additive or a process that causes it to become brittle

This is a big problem for me because, with kids, I don't always get a chance to run out and get new ones and having ones that constantly break is somewhat of a safety issue

Anyway, here is my answer to their manufacturing problem

This is a simpler design that requires adult dexterity to use. You need one hand to hold the base with at least two fingers and another hand to hold just the outside brim to pull out the cylinder. If you just pull on the knob, it will pull off the knob and gas won't come on anyway. Putting the top back on is easy to do with one hand

I still have one of these plugged in next to the stove just in case:
http://amzn.to/2EmtK3X
They're kind of nice because they just plug into an outlet and will let you know if you ever have a gas leak or a burner that's not closed all the way and isn't lit. It's really sensitive and will go off if a pot boils over and burner goes out or even if you're using some petroleum based aerosol can next to it

These are child resistant and not child proof (although I feel like they are much better than design I used to buy) use at your own risk, i'm not responsible, etc etc etc

As always, attached are the original sketchup file in case you need to make the bottom hole bigger or smaller or if you want to add anything. Let me know if you want me to make any updates, it'll take me a minute and I don't mind

Enjoy, and spend the money you save on something more useful like diapers or formula

Printer:

prusa i3 clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3 NO COOLING

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I tried making one without supports and it comes out ok if don't mind some stringy mess underneath the dome. The outside still looks fine, and depending on your printer settings, you may not see any stringing, but I saw some and it bothered me so I went with 70 degree supports for a perfect print. I printed on a hot bed (60c) with a 1mm skirt, depending on your PLA quality and print surface type you may need something different

This is mainly the PLA I used for these, but I used another kind also and it fit the same
http://amzn.to/2EmHHPj
They have it in silver and white and other colors you can get to match your stove

Try to print these with the same color as your stove. You can get PLA in silver to match stainless or white if your stove front is white. Mine was black, so I printed black so that the knobs blend in with the stove making it even less interesting for a kid to come over and mess with. Obviously don't print these in neon green or bright orange (unless you have a neon green or bright orange stove) because you don't want them to grab your kid's attention

The reason for no cooling is that given how thin the walls are, cooling it as it's printing will actually cause it to cool too quickly and you may get some unevenness at the first few layers because they are cooling too quickly. I noticed without cooling first few layers (and the rest) come out much cleaner for this particular part

the 70 degree supports are easily removed by hand, bic lighter burns off any stringing. the fit should be tight, but not so tight that it makes them difficult to use. I tested these with several types of PLA and it should work without scaling. If it's too tight or too loose for your liking (and/or print settings) you can scale the Top part up or down by .01% to get a fit you like. Another tip, take these off the heated platform right after they're done printing. If you let it sit there, it will cool unevenly and cause it to not go in as smoothly as it should

description.text:
This is a modified version of the "CICO Rescue Cricothyroidotomy Trainer - Vortex Approach" by drandybuck... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2530474

As per my comments in the original part, I've modified it to make it easier to print... a flat 'top' to the chin, which becomes the base when printing, and sloping the overhangs to 60degrees so that no support is needed. My print failed half-way through (printer parts getting a bit worn-out), so has an ugly glue join in the photos :(

At the request of our anaesthesiologist, I also increased the size of the holes through the 'neck' part, so that some plastic tubing could be inserted through the 'larynx' part, so that a complete 'airway' goes from the 'lungs' to the mouth.

The same larynx part fits into my 'neck' part.

I've also created a couple of connectors to attach the plastic tubing to the top and bottom of the 'larynx' so that the tubing doesn't need to go right through. That would require the gaps in the larynx part to be sealed up though, which I haven't done.

author: hatchetboy

description.text:
So 13thDiablo suggested i make this into a PI case...... there ya go! You will have to do some dremel work here but i think i've got the ports and holes in correct alignment.

Cheers

This is a Simchair MKIII 6 axis controller enclosure. The controller itself is an Arduino UNO (the one with atmega 16u2 on USB, e.g. original one or its exact clone) with a protoshield v 5 on top of it. A frame adaptor holds 4 8p8c sockets that are glued to it. The software for it is included (UnoJoy_10bit_3_axes_v1.1.zip). It allows up to 6 axes to be connected. It does not support buttons (i will design a separate button controller with wireless interface to support interchangeable wireless collective heads, cyclic grips, overhead panels etc after I will be done with mark III cyclic and pedals)

You will need:
Arduino UNO (https://goo.gl/2dhz99) x 1pcs (note that atmega 16u2 on USB is a MUST)
Arduino UNO Proto shield (https://goo.gl/kwKGgi) x 1pcs
8p8c sockets (https://goo.gl/i9XNi8) x4pcs
M3x50mm screws x4pcs
M3 nuts x 6pcs
some wires to solder sockets to the shield

This is intended to be used with IKEA GUNDE chair and Simchair MKIII frame, which is currently in development but can be used as a standalone joystick controller.

--UPDATE 11.02.2018

Uploaded updated firmware. Now we have 3 filtered 10 bit (1024 points instead of 255 for 8 bit) axes for cyclic and pedals!
Filtering levels are adjustable. It is done in both 328p and 16u2 code to prevent not only ADC and sensor noise but also the noise spikes developing from incorrect reads. Also, baud rate has been increased to 250000 (was 38400 before). Controls in the sim now look rock steady, no jittering can be seen at all. No need in the previous version anymore, so I have deleted it.

--UPDATE 14.02.2018
Firmware update. Added calibration for cyclic, to counter for printing settings/assembly differences, that can lead to displacement of centers of axes.

How to use UnoJoy software:

  1. Upload the "simchair.ino" sketch to your Arduino with an Arduino IDE.
  2. Install Atmel FLIP.
  3. Turn your Arduino into DFU mode.
  4. Your board should come up as an atmega16u2.
  5. Run "Turn into a joystick.bat"
  6. Replug your board and it will show up as a joystick.

Note that ALL analog inputs MUST be either connected to potentiometers or grounded. You can use dummy RJ45 plugs for that (just wire pins 2 to 6 together).

Ethernet cable connections:
White-orange: +5v
Orange: Ground
White-Green: Collective axis
Blue: Throttle 1 axis
White-Blue: Throttle 2 axis

Use the T-568B standard wire order for all your connections (see picture below).

Analog inputs should be connected as follows to match the text on the cover of enclosure:

Sockets from the right (pedals) to the left (cyclic):
pin 1 is always 5v
pin 2 is always GND

Socket 1 (pedals), pin 3 to analog input 5

Socket 2 (collective): pin 3 to analog input 3
pin 4 to analog input 2
pin 5 to analog input 4

Socket 3 (cyclic): pin 3 to analog input 1
pin 4 to analog input 0
Socket 4 (spare)

title: Surfboard Replacement Fin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi i wanted to share with you all this design for a replacement fin for soft boards.
i tried to search for a similar item thinking a STL file was easily available online but failed to find anything close to create a replacement item. So after some 5 or 6 revs later i came up with this design which works well & seems a very acceptable replacement option.

This is just a basic push in softboard fin secured by a threaded 30mm location pin retainer + 36mm long x 30mm wide head screw as a replacement fin for the cheaper softboards, soft surf boards and the soft body boards.

You can buy this items on eBay for about $30 Australian, but hay this is a 3D Printing website & a challenge … plus I’m too tight to pay $30 + postage and wait over 4 weeks for the item.

This is a partial remix / redesign of the canoe fin by JANMES12 ... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964373

i chose this fin design as it is very sturdy (at 13mm thick) and practical for diy home 3D printing. Some of the thinner more finesse designs were not sturdy enough to justify the printing fail rate and abuse they are going to get during use and in transit.

i added a wider load spreading flange & the two push in 30mm threaded locating pins, these were ~93mm apart on my soft body board & surf board.

i created 2 options of fin heights ... ~50mm & ~90mm fin, of course you can cut this fin off and insert any other design you want on to the mounting plate.

I suggest you use at least 50% fill for the fins & 100% fill for the retaining screws.

The screw is 35mm long x 30mm wide head, has an external size of 7mm thread for the bolt shaft & the nut receiver side of 8.5mm therefore a tolerance of 0.75mm each side which seems quite big & slack but works well. This also has a 2.5mm coin slot for tightening and removing (which is just right for the largest 2.4mm thick Australian 50 cent coin.)

When mounting the Pin + screw it has a total board thickness clearance of ~60mm to ~42mm if you need a smaller gap for a smaller board thickness then cut the screws down by 5mm then retry so you get max thread grip overlap length.

Using Cura to produce the GCode, I printed in an upright position & used a “everywhere” or “Touching Base Plate” support option, which works well but the only drawback is the internal female thread also gets a support mesh printed inside which needs removed or poked out on completion, I used a combination of 4mm wire, long nose plyers & wire flat head screw driver, but not too big it will damages the internal helix threads.

For Cura Set up see screen grabs.
See Post printing images for more supporting and detailed photos.

I’m always learning so any good constructive feedback or links to other similar items are welcome.

Thanks for reading.

author: zenip

description.text:
I downloaded a GT2 pully from somewhere, I thought it was accurate.
I discovered that not only were some of it's dimensions different from the actual idlers I had in my possession, but that the flanges and channels around the bore were completely incorrect.
When designing I often rely on the accuracy of these small dimensions... eg: how big a washer, bolthead or spacer can be before it is no longer bearing only on the inner flange and therefore causes friction on the outer (spinning) components.
So I made this from scratch. It's not 100% accurate, as apparently there is no exact specification document online that I could find, but I have measured the critical bearing surface around the M3 bore, and the various gaps and protrusions surrounding it, and have modelled those accurately enough for me to consider useful to use as a basis for design at the ~100micron resolution level.

TL;DR; it's not to print, it's to design around. AFAIK it's the most commonly available idler of it's kind on aliexpress.

2018-02-02--16-00-31
deleted 806 kb stl from 01/30/2018
added new file - includes added detail to bearing (3x6x2.5mm MR63ZZ) construction and it's mounting within the idler. Details of the bearing's side profile (the ZZ, the part that protects and retains the actual ball bearings) are still not totally correct; without getting my microscope out I had to measure and guess a little under about 8x diopters of magnification, but it's still pretty accurate as far as what the bolt can bear on without binding the rotational freedom of the bearing outer.

2018-02-04--15-48-47
deleted 1 mb from 02/02/2018
added 0.05mm axial gap between bearing seats in idler casing.. just to keep the bearing from fusing with the idler. This makes it easier to eliminate duplicate vertices with much higher degree of accuracy without unnecessarily merging vertices from discrete objects.
TL;DR: they should 'split' (be separable) in your slicer AND your 3D editor better now.

title: Hi-ratio Planetary gearing - combine industrial spur gears with 3D prints
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For a stepper application I needed a planetary gearing system (PG) with a ratio of 16, reasonable dimensions, good precision, and first of all high torque transmission with minimal backlash. My idea was to compose a special one-stage PG design by reusing industrial gears. Here are the basic considerations.

  1. The precision of 3D printed gears is very low. Therefore especially multi-stage gearing systems needed for higher ratios suffer from high backlash.
  2. For reasonable printing results a module > 1.5 must be chosen, which leads to large dimensions. The ratio of a one-stage PG in classical design is limited to about i=9. While you can obtain such a ratio with a 3D printed system, you’ll end up with some very large structure (>170mm diameter).
  3. In my stock are countless gears in high industrial quality (e.g. from cannibalized printers) which I couldn’t combine into a PG, mainly because ring gears with such “small” modules can’t be 3D-printed with reasonable quality and torque resistance. I also have a box full of steppers already equipped with high quality “sun” gears. Unfortunately, the module is too small to directly combine them with 3D printed parts.

The solution I found addresses all three points. It combines a first stage system with given sun and planets in high industrial quality and small module m1 from stock with a second stage system (Planets and Ring) for gaining a multiplied ratio i=i1*i2.

The second stage system will be (automatically) calculated with a much larger module m2, provided a reasonable setup with i1 <= i2 is used. Gears with m2 > 1.5 can easily be 3D-printed in reasonable height to also fully account for the increased torque t2 at output which calculates as t1*i.

To give you an impression of the range and sizes the code generates, I have uploaded a couple screenshots of nice designs with different gear ratios and modules m1. The parameter values for reconstruction can be taken from the console output below the viewport.

My little video Hi-ratio Planetary Gear Set contains an animation of a design demonstrating the fixed-Ring and fixed carrier operation, as well as my first printout around a given industrial gear set with modulus 1 comprising a sun and two planet spurgears with 10 and 50 teeth respectively.

Design your own

The code has a parameter section, where you can adjust the design to your needs. Start by choosing a module m1, a ratio i1 (with 2<i1<8) and a sun gear tooth count zs for the first stage system as well as the number N of planets, such that zs/N is an integer. Then select a ratio i2 with 2<i2<=i1) and a tooth count zP for the second stage planets, such that zP/N is an integer.
The code currently does not check, whether N is too large for the planets to fit around the sun. Use the preview (F5) to sort this out.
In verbose mode the code outputs the core information of your design in the console as shown in the following screenshot.

The Code

For displaying the full system, ensure that the system() command (line 52) is uncommented. When uncommenting the print() command (line 53) also uncomment the appropriate lines in module print(). This allows you to F6-render the parts of choice for STL-export.
You can switch the hb flag to enable herringbone gearing for the second stage system. Rendering is quite fast (usually <1 minute) when tooth counts are moderate and the parts are rendered separately by print(). The following image shows the print layout I used for the system in the video.

The libraries

The code heavily uses the latest versions of two of my favorite libraries introduced in earlier Thingiverse projects.
Shortcuts.scad defines simplifying synonyms for many important OpenSCAD keywords (affine transformations, Boolean operations, geometric primitives) as well as macros for additional primitives (loop types, geometric elements). Sorry for this additional severity, but it speeds up coding so much, and also enhances code readabilty, once you understood the naming convention.

gears.scad offers an easy-to-use box of gear types. It is fully parametrized and allows for a fast design of arbitrary gearing systems.

Both libraries offer a help() module, which outputs the module prototypes to the console.

Finally, I have successfully tested the code with OpenSCAD 2015.3 and the currently newest development snapshot 2018.1.6.

description.text:
Here is a replacement for Z motor mount of Prusa i3 MK2/MK2s/mk2.5 and MK3 printers. This fix the dimensions error on Z axis (issue 49)

Features

  • Stronger
  • Compatible with MK2, MK2s, MK2.5 and MK3
  • Fix issue 49
  • Quick remove of Z motor for maintenance
  • Tab on the back for perfect alignment
  • Dimensions of original Z mounts optimized for PETG
  • Z smooth rod are maintained in 7mm deep hole (instead of 5mm)
  • Selective infill technique to add strength on critical points
  • Use M3x12mm to fix the motor (instead of M3x10mm)
  • Open source by providing STL, STEP and Fusion 360 files

/!\ Warning /!\

  1. Use M3x12mm to fix the motor (instead of the original M3x10mm)!
  2. Follow carefully to the print settings bellow because there is selective infill inside the part

Check out my Z top fix for a very strong and fine tuned Z axis : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2552246

Changelog

v1.0 : increase rod hole dia by 0.05
v1.1 : improve print quality inside the smooth rod hole, make Nema 17 a bit more tighten
v1.2 : add tab on back for best alignment with the frame (not tested yet, v1.1 still available) That was a bad idea, we cannot guarantee that the holes are perfectly aligned with the border of the frame.

Thanks for the awesome work done by Josef Prusa and team!

Portable FDM Printer

I wanted to have a printer that can be transported easy without being damaged in transport.So I made this printer :-)
The housing is as small as possible while keeping standard print dimensions. This one can print 200x200x380mm. To keep it light, the housing is made from 9mm plywood. It is basically a square box with the printer mounted inside. So you can make your own housing or frame. Of course the housing is an advantage if you want to print ABS. Then I wanted this printer as fast as possible, because there’s not always much time, printing on site :-). Therefore I used a Bowden setup and a very light X and Y car. The vase printed in the picture is printed at 60mm/s in PLA. I want to test this printer with higher speed, but didn’t have time jet. The Red fan ducts on the side of the nozzle are not my own design (RoPa here on Thingiverse : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1264477).

Because my printers are very often connected to polluted mains (there are welding, milling and grinding machines nearby), there is a simple mains filter build in. This filter kills most of the EMF frequencies to the Arduino. The Atmel chip can do strange things under EMF stress. Normally I prefer a second ferrite coil but I didn’t have one. For the schematic please see the picture. Note that the capacitors need to be of an X2 and Y2 class so that if they die they are guaranteed not to short out. C1 & C2 need to be of class X2. C3 & C4 need to be of class Y2. Also this filter needs to be in a metal case (see picture) and must be earthed always!

The controller is an Arduino and a Ramps 14 running on marlin. I included the marlin.ino in the Zip file.For information about configuring Marlin you could consult : http://marlinfw.org/docs/configuration/configuration.html

To hold the Teflon tubing in place, I used a gland nut. For some reason the original tube holders I have do not work very well.

Note:

for info about the corner handles see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753575
for info about the full graphic smart controller panel see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2756248
for info about the Extruder see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2749974
for Extruder motor cooler see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2347821

If you have questions or do you think I forgot something, feel free to ask or comment :-)

Parts List for the printer:

2X 608Z bearing
4XGT2 wheel with bearing (bore 3mm) (F625zz)
2XGT2 pulley 5mm bore
2X T2 timing belt (length is determined by the length of the X and Y axis)
2X 8mm spindles and nut ,trapezoid (or treated rode 8mm and M8 nut)
4X Linear bearing LM8UU for the 8mm rods
8X Linear bearing LM10UU for the 10 mm rods
1X drive gear (26 teeth) for extruder
4X gliding rod 10mm (length is determined by the length of the Z & Y axis)
2X gliding rod 8mm (length is determined by the length of the X axis)
2X T2 timing belt (length is determined by the length of the X and Y axis)
3X Nema 17 stepper motor (such as 3X SHENLI SL42S247A 2,5A or Wantai 42BYGHW811)
2X Nema 17 stepper motor for Z axis with max length of 38mm (such as 42BYGHW208)
1X Hot End (heater, heater block, Heat break and Thermistor 100K)
1X Heat Bed (MK3 Aluminum) & Thermistor 100K & 4 springs
1X spring for Extruder
2X Teflon Tube Holder or wartel (gland nut)
1X Teflon tube (length depends on the height of the z Axis)
1X Ramps 14
1X Arduino Mega
4X Stepper driver (DRV8825, A4988 or TMC2100)
1X Power supply 12V 360W and wire for the motors, switches etc.
3X End switch
1X mains power inlet
1X fuse holder
3x 30x30mm fan
1X 80x80mm fan
1X mains switch
1X 12v switch and led strip
1X LED 5mm for back light SD Card slot
Wood panel 9mm for the housing
Poly carbonate glass plate 2mm
Woodscrews 6mm
Glue
Paint for the housing

Bolts & Nuts

For the Heat Bed & Y axis :
33X M3 nut
4X M3 x40mm
4X M3 X20mm
24X M3 x10mm
4X M3 x6mm

For the X axis and car:
20X M3 nut
2X M3 x40mm
18X M3 x20mm
4X M3 x6mm

For the Z axis:
13X M3 nut
13X M3 X10mm
8X M3 X6mm
If you think I forgot something on this list, please inform me :-)

Bolts, nuts & screws for the housing are not included in this list. If you want to know feel free to ask :-)
The hinges use M4 x60mm bolts

comments.text: I was wondering if you could tell me how big the outside dimensions of the printer box are?
comments.author: Jett0312

comments.text:
581mm high, 410mm on the front and 425mm deep (filament side). But keep in mind that the 425mm is calculated on an 200x200mm heat bed. Most of the heat beds have a dimension of something like 220x220mm. If you are using one of those the 425mm must become at least 465mm. Otherwise the printer will not be able to make full use of the total printing space.
Also these dimensions are calculated to work with 9mm plate. If you have more questions feel free to ask :-)

description.text:
I am a renter and didn't see any spool holders/racks/brackets that could be mounted with command strips instead of screws. So I designed my own. These are designed to use the "medium" 3M Command Strips (tm). I've hung about 1.5kg off just one bracket for a day. I am using a pair to hold two 1kg spools of filament and I'm using 20cm of 8mm threaded rod. If they turn out to fall/pull off I'll redesign them to use the large Command Strips (tm).

ps: Thanks to AristoDesign who's design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2755427) was the inspiration for this bracket.

2018.02.20 Update:
It's been about a month and one set has been holding an unused 1kg spool of PETG and a slightly used 0.5kg spool of PLA. Both spools are mounted with Ansen Slot inserts (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:338669) and 608zz bearings. More impressively they've held up to my 2yr old pulling on them and spinning the spools. I suspect the medium Command Strips (tm) will suffice for two 1kg spools.

title: Prusa i3 mk2s centered bed camera mount

description.text:
HEY! DON'T DOWNLOAD OR PRINT THIS UNLESS YOU HAVE A PI CAMERA V1. EVEN THEN LOOK AT V2 first and consider contributing a remix to it as that is an improved overall design addressing the problems mentioned below.

I wanted to center my raspberry pi camera and built this thing to do that. It fits my i3 mk2s and may fit other versions as well? If anyone would like to buy me the mk3, I'd be happy to test it ;)

I used the camera case here. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:467182 before I realized I have the pi camera 2 which doesn't fit. I made it work for now.

This design has a few flaws that I may try to fix in the future. The camera mount, as mentioned above is just not right. This means that I sort of had to hack things together for now. This also results in the camera being higher than I would ideally like. Something to address in a future release.

Another problem is that the channels that fit the bottom of the stand bump a bit against the y axis frame. I was able to get it to work by pulling out on the channel brackets a bit before attaching, but if I do it again I'll have them cut off a bit on the inside to avoid that problem.

include

Servo myservo; // create servo object to control a servo

// variable to read the value from the analog pin

void setup() {
myservo.attach(7); // attaches the servo on pin 9 to the servo object
}

void loop() {
// scale it to use it with the servo (value between 0 and 180)
myservo.write(175);

delay(350); // waits for the servo to get there
myservo.write(45);

delay(350); // waits for the servo to get there
}

title: CTC Anet A8 Rear Frame Brace

description.text:
While building a new printer (CTC Anet A8 clone) i found there to be alot of flexibility in the frame, and i was not happy about 2 little ply formers holding the front of the Y-Axis in place.

So i designed this to combat that problem, and so far i am very happy with the results.

Printer:

Hictop Pursa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

45%

Notes:

Please ensure your supports are easily removable, or you will have difficulty in some places.

My Settings

Support Pattern - ZigZag
Infill - 25%
Support Interface
thickness - 1mm (Top and bottom)
Distance - 0.2
Pattern - Grid
Infil - 15%

Post-Op

Remove all supports,

Pay particular attention to the Nut locations on the Stepper Location,

May require re-drilling of some holes in frame due to manufacturers differences.

Designed by myself on F360,

Inspiration taken from others in regards to the honeycomb centre.

Installation.

Ok, so this actually slides onto the threaded bar, and is captivated by the nuts, effectivly clamping it in place.

Ensure the stepper bolts are in place, as this will reduce strain on the part, and ensure a more secure stepper.

The front middle 2 bolts are not required, but can be fitted if you would like.

There are holes underneath the threaded bar to allow routing of cables.
The additional piece of Ply that doubles up the rear frame section is no longer required.

This is for the CTC Anet A8 (Ply Frame) with 160mm between frames.

description.text:
Due to requests and me having some time, here's a "Mildly Infuriated Porg".

Like the other one, is based in several sketches from Star Wars.

This Porg has the characteristic of when seen from below, it looks calm and happy. But from above it looks like the devil. So don't be eluded by that cute happy face, the real Porg is seen from above.

Also, you know what happens when they have the higher ground?!

Notes:

I removed all the internal structure in the skull mostly, thickened and thinned some walls, removed the bottom jaw/beak. For added strength I print with 3 outer walls.

Once the files printed in PLA, I sand them, use a lighter to get any rough edges smoothed then I hot glue all four pieces together. After that, I use acrylic paint to cover up any visible hot glue, then I rub tea candle wax over the entire surface of the print. After that, I light a tea candle and carefully dance the flame over the un-melted wax until it melts and spreads itself evenly over the PLA surface. This gives the file a nice feel to the touch and makes it shiny.

I found an old Velcro VR headset strap I used to attach the mask to my face. Your on your own here, find something to match whatever color your final mask would be.

title: Pinewood derby (slow but great lessons learned)

description.text:
Had a blast doing this for a fundraiser at work.

This was my attempt at a pinewood derby car. Full disclosure, it was slow as hell lol. Huge lesson learned is bearings sound good on paper but are actually have a ton of drag. Rest of the car design worked pretty well. If I did it again I will redesign it to not have bearings and probably a small pin or something like that. Also the frame wasn't stiff enough to keep the smaller wheel off the ground.

Used 3/16 rods I cut to length for the axels, RC car bearings, lead shot as ballast, and a magnet in the front (thought the gate was going to be iron, it wasn't).

Great tech paper here (not written by me) https://www.mech-sci.net/3/73/2012/ms-3-73-2012.pdf about pinewood derby dynamics.

Keys:

  • Overall CG (center of gravity) needs to be as low as possible and towards the rear of the car. Thing like tungsten over lead help but I sure as hell wasn't paying $25-$30 for 3 oz of tungsten when lead shot is so cheap. Also CG should be in front of rear axle by 5-10mm for stability.
  • Overall car weight needs to be a certain weight and no heavier. By standard pinewood derby rules its pretty much max weight.
  • Wheels second moment of inertia (weight in the wheel as close to spinning axis as possible) as small as possible. IE a spinning CD versus a spinning wedding ring weighing exactly the same the spinning CD is better.
  • Wheels overall weight as low as possible
  • Overall friction is crucial, minimize as much as possible. 3 wheels touch versus 4. Polished axles, perfect holes, no rubbing wheel on chassis, Teflon spacers on wheels. Low coefficient of friction materials.
  • Alignment theoretically should be straight but due to nature of track most people track their vehicles to one side very slightly, maybe a better way to do this would be to tighten would the track width to just a little wider then the track.

Cheating (depending on who you talk to):

  • Sticky nose on gate (gate pulls vehicle forward)

Oh well maybe next year.

Mimic Chest
This is a mimic chest - a monster that disguises itself as a wooden box to fool people.

Project #4: Office Supply Storage Problem Statement:
Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of two has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy just one; they will want to buy the whole set.
OPTIONS:
Pen/Pencil holder that can securely hold at least 5 pencils
Expo marker holder than can securely hold at least 4 markers
Tape dispenser that will hold and cut a roll of scotch tape
Paper clips/etc. dish
Phone docking station
USB Stick/SD card holder
Custom Paper Clips
Anything you can get approved by your project manager! Constraints:
You will be constructing an actual size model of your product in Solidworks
It should be cool to look at and unique - a conversation starter. An individual walking by would do a double take to more closely examine the amazingly interesting item you’ve created.
It should contain examples of ALL FOUR main features: extrusion, revolve, sweep, loft
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: circular pattern, linear pattern, mirror
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: filleting, chamfering
Each piece you design should fit within a 10cm x 10cm x 10cm cube
Should be 3D printable with limited/no supports Deliverables (Each of the following steps must be approved by me before moving to the next step):
3D and 2D sketches of your ideas (upload pictures)
Planning for Solidworks “How-To” (Design Notebook)
Bulleted Outline on Google Docs
Use the pencil planning document as a template
Solidworks: Actual size model of your product
Thingiverse pages for each design

https://www.thingiverse.com/MCDeltaT/collections/office-supply-organizer-projects/

title: Headphone Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked the headphone holder by Stevetecx because it's small, simple, and looks nice. My only problem was that it was structurally weaker than it needed to be. I reduced the overall length so it's now sized to hold heaphones with a maximum headband of 4cm. I also fattened out the bottom, keeping a taper, to help transfer weight from the tip of the holder to the base.

I also changed the orientation of the model so it prints the strongest possible structure.

Stevetecx says to use a 3,5x16 Screw. I just found a screw that I had left over from another project that ended up being a bit bigger. It caused a small split, but the holder is still strong enough now that I don't have to worry if my cat steps on it.

title: DemonDeltaTube - Delta Printer in an acrylic tube

description.text:
DemonDeltaTube Printer

Update 08-03-2018 Added a carriage suitable for anti-backlash nuts. It is 1mm shorter as the antibacklash nuts springs take up a small amount of space and this affects the leadscrew to nut alignment.

See here for detailed build log http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?178,802910,page=1

This is a repository of the parts for this machine if you want to emulate it. Please attribute.

I have added most of the parts for this machine, extruder is up to you depending on what you want to fit. Recommend ABS/PETG as it does get quite hot inside.

Effector -

Update 11-02-18 Added hole in effector for hotend wiring which was useful as I was assembling it.

Integrates Precision Piezo - Piezo20 nozzle contact sensor (requires a suitable amplifier such as https://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/product-page/copy-of-piezo-signal-pcb-kit-version) to function, and a drilled 20mm piezo disc, some modification to the endstop cable headers is required currently. Designed for genuine e3d v6 (with integrated miniature bowden coupler), recesses in the side for bonding 30mm blower fans (https://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/product-page/sunon-blower-radial-fan-5v) space to attach a 30x30x10 fan from the e3d kit, designed to work on the 55mm spacing magball system (Haydn Huntley https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/deltabot/485cfVFrFFU/feT5lm8WfIwJ). Assemble piezo sensor as per documentation at https://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/documents

Make sure magarms are arranged with negative and positive poles at the effector end on each pair of arms, so the arms attract each other when disconnected from the effector. This balances the magnetic fields around the effector otherwise they stop the fans from spinning properly.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

Like a few other people, I cracked the end off my idler during some aggressive construction. The original design carries a fair bit of force through a narrow section with tension between layers - the weakest dimension in a 3D print. So, here's a design that's a bit stronger where it pivots.

• Drill out the hole for the pivot bolt in the main extruder piece. Make sure the bolt moves freely within it. If things don't seem well aligned when you continue assembly, perhaps loosen this hole a bit further.

  • Clean out the slotted holes where the tension screws go, to ensure free movement there too.

  • Insert the idler bearing with its pin.
    • Bolt front-to-back with lock nuts
  • Clean out the idler's pivot holes so bolt moves freely.
  • Expand the counter-sink hole in E-idler sufficiently for the head of the pivot bolt; this will keep the head out of the way of the big extruder gear.
  • Attach idler to main extruder body, with bolt. Add 2x lock nuts; tighten these against each other, but not against the plastic.
    • Bolt back-to-front
  • Optional - clean recessed hole and insert a hex nut.
  • Attach idler to main extruder body, with bolt head at rear of extruder.

description.text: Alternative bearing holder for X axis carriage on TAZ 3D Printer. I noticed the nozzle wobbling in the X axis and believed this was down to the use of only three bearings on the X axis carriage, so I bought a new bearing and created this alternative part to house an additional bearing. This has removed the wobble and prints come out much nicer. This work was derived from LulzBot's original TAZ 2.0 designs. https://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/2.0/

• Buy a new linear bearing from Lulzbot for $4.95
    • https://www.lulzbot.com/products/solid-polymer-bearing-rjm-01-10mm
  • Print the bearing holder and mount it with all of the existing bolts and connectors. You need to loosen and slide back the X-Axis rails to put the part on the X-Axis carriage. It's quite easy to do.

title: Cable chain (and addons) for auluminium profiles, CNC routers/engravers

description.text:
This is "yet another cable chain". This one, I've made to better fit in aluminium profile used in most of the cheap CNC routers/engravers.

Project consist of:

  • cable input shaft - fitting in the aluminium profile
  • chain links, with small notches - when moving, it directs chain over the middle of the profile
  • cable output element - it fits into stepper motor "collar", because of it you can regulate distance from the stepper
  • stepper motor collar - that should fit on usually used sizes for CNC and 3D printers. You can screw the collar to the stepper, but it will work just fine without it

Releases:

  • Version 1.1
    • updated collar: longer wall around stepper, wider cable output space, cable holder in front
  • Version 1.0 - initial release

description.text:
Since I got my Wanhao D6, I wanted to make the spool holder better, so it can fit all (or at least most) types of filaments. I have seen many here, and also printed many and they either do not work or I need to go shopping for parts like I need to build a SUV axle.

So, here is a solution that works like a charm with no moving parts, and no need to go buy nuts, bolts, ball bearings and shafts.

The spool holder is long enough for all filaments that I've tried, but not too long to make bulk on the back side. The limiter plug has 3 holes to be put in, depending on the filament spool thickness. If you have a really really thick spool (I have a few) than you can remove the limiter plug completely, and the cap on the top will act as a limiter itself.

TIP 01: If you want to print the top cover without support, flip the cover face down, and lower it below the print surface for the depth of the RF badge. You will be able to print without support, but without the RF badge. Also no need for raft.

TIP 02: If you need the M30 nut, you can download it from this fine gentleman (I did also):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752310

TIP 03: I also made a filament clip-holder, but than I saw a 10 times better one, so I trashed mine and downloaded it here from this fine gentleman:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1799179

Sorry if the files are not top-notch. I'm a graphic designer, still getting a hang of 3D

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Print Settings for the spool holder:
Orientation: Vertical
0.2mm layer
Raft: Recommended (3mm offset is fine)
Support: Yes
Infill: 50-100%*

*I printed one on 50% and one on 100%, the one on 50% seems to be strong enough, but when I was tightening it I felt a little bit of cracking, so I printed another one on 100% for the peace of mind.

Print Settings for the limiter plug:
Orientation: Horizontal, face up.
0.1mm layer (if you want it to look neat)
Raft: Not needed
Support: No
Infill: 100%

Print Settings for the top cover:
Orientation: Horizontal, face up
0.1mm layer (if you want it to look neat)
Raft: Recommended (2mm offset is fine)

Infill: 100%

Print Settings for the back plate (ADDON):
Orientation: Horizontal, face up
0.1mm layer (if you want it to look neat)
Raft: Recommended (2mm offset is fine)
Support: No
Infill: 100%
If it turns out that something fits too tight, it could be only due to material contraction, just do a little magic with some sandpaper.

llavero :v
A mounting bracket for a 40mm fan with integral duct that directs cooling airflow towards the extruder tip of a Printrbot 3d printer.

I have a Printrbot LC Plus.  This bracket inserts between the extruder and the extruder carriage.  The fan is a 40x40x10mm dc fan.  You will want a 12v fan to use with the Printrboard that comes with the Printrbot.  RadioShack sells the fan, or you can find it at Amazon, DigiKey, Mouser, Fry's, etc.  The Printrboard uses a two-wire fan.
There are alignment studs on the bracket for the fan screw holes.  I tacked it on with CA glue then ran a bead of RTV silicone around the periphery to make sure there was no bleed air out the sides.  Make sure you have the polarity correct when you connect it to the Printrboard.  You can easily check to see if the fan is turning the right direction by placing a post-it note to the fan.  It it sticks, the fan is blowing the right direction.  I find it hard to tell by feeling it with so little airflow.

title: Easy Print & Glue - Panzerjäger I
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I startet printing vehicles I often was frustrated about the deficient print quality and the awful cleaning work.

So I decided to divide the object into several parts.
The focus is on print quality and avoiding support structures.
After printing, the parts have to be glued together.

Meanwhile I printed and built some models in this way.

I publish the print files for all users which like to have quick and good prints results.

I publish the files under the title "Easy Print & Glue"

Finally let my thank the original designers of the models. They are important for our community. I only cut their models into several pieces ... nothing else.

=======================================

This time I worked on the Panzerjäger I.

I took this object, cutted it into several pieces and printed it with my FDM printer at a scale of 1/72.

All parts should printed with support. But there are only a few areas were support is really needed, mainly the gun and the barrel.
The support can be removed quick and easy.

title: Concrete Planter Mold - Intermediate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I've had the idea of casting a concrete planter out of a 3D printed mold for quite some time.
After failing with Verbatim ABS I picked up some Zen filament and went to town.

There are two files:
Identical_Mold_Side - This can be printed twice, I measured it out to 11cm across.

Mold_Spout - This is inserted into the bottom of the mold, I tried to scale it down 2%
however tolerances on printers may differ.

I purposfully printed the spout a bit smaller to leave gaps at the bottom that I filled with prestik to keep the sides together before taping it up.

After prepping the piece I think used simple cooking spray on the inside so the concrete does not stick. (Bare in mind I used Kwik-crete, which is a fast acting concrete filler used for fitting bolts to walls)

I also used duct tape to hold the two sides together, a future iteration of this should include some parts to help connect it better.

The curing time took around 2 hours in the mold, after that simply pull it apart slowly and let the model dry for another 24-48 hours.

It may seem crude and rough however it actually works like a charm and the spout simply slides out.

I hope you enjoy the model, would love to see any other creations!

Printer Brand:

Duplicator 4

Printer:

Wanhao

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed this at 50mm/s with Zen 3D PLA
205 on the hotend and 60 on the printbed.

2 Shells and a diamond infill of 10%

We aren't done yet!

After letting the concrete cure and dry, I went over it a few times with sandpaper.

Once I achieved the desired effect I bought some concrete solvent and applied a layer every hour for 3 hours which gave it that nice dark concrete look.

Additionally you could buy some spray paints and decorate it as you see fit, however I have noticed that the "chalk-board" effect came out better and is aesthetically pleasing as well as a conversation starter or gift.

title: ESP12-E Wireless Clock - WS2812b housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What?

ESP12-E / ESP8266 board housing with mounts for a WS2812b 12-LED ring.

Hour hand: Red, Minutes: Green, Seconds: Blue
Since minutes are in increments of 5, I've also added "Purple minutes" - IE if it's 7 after, you'll see the green LED on the 5 mark, and two additional purple LEDs will be lit.

How?

You can make it do flashy things, or use it as a wifi time synced clock.

Github source code: https://github.com/gunkl/esp12e-clock

The current binary for the clock is here: https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/ds01222018-mypublicbucket/public/esp-clock12.ino.bin

You can set the wifi ssid and password as well as UTC offset by following the menu system via the serial console. Connect at 115200.

I used the HiLetgo WS2812b 12-LED ring obtained from Amazon.
Connect GPIO14 to the DI wire on the LED ring. Use standard resistor and cap wiring for power (+Vin to 330ohm resistor to LED+, GND to LED, 63+uF cap from +Vin to Gnd)

Notes

Currently no daylight savings automatic support.

No echo-back on serial during config, so be prepared to enable local echo.

To Do

Add daylight savings support

Make a new lid design that's a little more aesthetically pleasing.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

75% or more

Notes:

Use a brim on the lid as it can warp easily.
No supports on the base or lid.

For the light pipe section (use clear/transparent PLA), flip it over (bottom-down) and add a support grid sufficient for your printer, so that it comes out looking nice. I set my support grid to 25% infill with 2mm XY spacing.

The pieces should snap together a little snugly, if you take it apart be careful not to leave the pins from the lid inside the body, but if you do, a small screw will make quick work to remove it.
