title: 2" NPT cap for Maxbotix USB ultrasonic sensor (oil tank level readings)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I found the Maxbotix ultrasonic sensors to be quite good for monitoring the level in our home heating oil tank, but up to this point I was buying a 2" NPT PVC pipe plug and swapping that into a blank spot in the top of the tank. This required careful drilling of the pipe plug, and the end result worked but didn't look good.

This thing started out life as a a 3D model from McMaster-Carr, which I modified with provision for the Maxbotix USB sensor with a side port access for the USB cable. See "How I Designed This" below for more details.

Previously, I've used the Maxbotix sensors with TTL serial output (MB1043) but they've since released a USB model which is far easier to work with, so I've customized this thing for use with the MB1443 USB sensor.

Maxbotix has several tutorials on using their sensors with a Raspberry Pi:

  • Older tutorial for serial sensors: Interfacing a Raspberry Pi with an ultrasonic sensor
  • More current tutorial for USB sensors: Connect a Raspberry Pi Zero with an USB Ultrasonic Sensor

Here's a video showing a time lapse of my data compared to the actual physical float level on the oil tank showing how well it matches up: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Ic_27f4kBo

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with 4 shells and 2mm top and bottom.

Looking through thingiverse for some hardware, I came across this pipe plug by marshalltjones and saw in the description "This .stl file model was extracted from a McMaster Carr cafe file for a 3/4 inch NPT plug....I didn't create it." I knew that McMaster made many parts available with CAD files, but it had never dawned on me to use those to directly 3D print something. So, I went to McMaster's website and found a 2" NPT thick wall PVC pipe plug and downloaded the "3-D STEP" file. I imported that into FreeCAD, and then exported that as an STL.

I then went to the Maxbotix site and downloaded the STL file for the MB1443 USB sensor so I could use that as a template.

Once I had the STL files, I brought that into SketchUp (as that's what I'm currently most familiar with) and made the cutout for the sensor in the underside of the cap, with a hole in the side for the USB cable.

Loutrophore, the exhibition of the dead around 500-480 BCE. Musée du Cinquantenaire (Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap from AutoDesk.

Loutrophorus was used to transport water used in rites of purification prior to weddings or funerals. In the case of a funeral rite, the women of the house cleanse the body before coating it with scented oil and dressing it to place it on a funeral bed. Identical vases were also used to mark graves or offerings.

The board and wedge where used to tilt the cannon barrel. I included these, but they are not needed for the print. There is also an assembled model Cannon.stl if you want to print it in one piece, but then the barrel and wheels will be fixed.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The bore of the cannon might need some support when printing. It depends on the size you print and your printer. Better safe than sorry.
Print two of these files:
carrige
front_wheel
rear_wheel

Glue the A and B parts together (barrel, front and rear axel) before assembly.
You need to make a hole for a small pin to avoid the front wheels falling off. Some eye bolts for ropes can also be added to make the model more detailed (too small print on the model).

I designed this for a few different photos I found online. I cannot publish these photos as I do not have distribution rights to these photos. I used sketchup to build the model and cut the pieces for printing.

author: DavidKa

title: Laser Support (for laser up to 24mm  diameter)

description.text:
This is a support for laser up to 24mm!

/!\ /!\ WARNING /!\ /!\
If you open the stl file, the piece is really too big. It's because i made it with Sketchup and i'm a beginner, so with this "method", i could make it with a greater precision.

You have to resize it to 5% ! both of them.

I made it for Explore Scientific embase, but it could be adapt for other telescope, i think...

Bonjour!

Voilà un support laser pour l'astronomie (laser jusque 24mm de diamètre!)

/!\ /!\ ATTENTION /!\ /!\

Les pièces sur les STL sont clairement trop grande, il faut donc les redimensionner à 5% pour avoir leur taille réelle. J'ai volontairement fait la pièce 20x plus grande sur sketchup car il est plus simple d'ajuster la précision des diamètres sur les anneaux & la base!

Il a été fait avec les mesures de mon dobson Explore Scientific, mais je pense que la base est compatible avec d'autres telescopes... !

Screw & nut 6 x M3x20 screw (for alignement)
2 x M3x10 screw (for fixation ring/support)
2 x M3 nuts (for locking fixation screws)

author: emilecantin

print_settings.Notes:: Be sure to inspect the infill for connection from the walls to the screw holes. At least two intersecting walls are required to build a sturdy mount. Increase infill if necessary.

description.text:
An enclosure/battery holder for the GM328 transistor tester. The box has a simple hinge that holds the battery in place under the tester, while leaving the board surface perfectly flush on the enclosure's rounded edge. This leaves all the features of the tester easily accessible, such as the sop contacts.

The enclosure is a tight fit around the pcb (<0.1mm gap). Push firmly the pcb until it snaps into place. M3 screws can be directly fastened on the support.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Be sure to inspect the infill for connection from the walls to the screw holes. At least two intersecting walls are required to build a sturdy mount. Increase infill if necessary.

comments.text: I just uploaded my box and gave you credit for inspiration!
comments.author: wimberleytech

comments.text: This is a great idea.  I have one of the variations on this tester that tests transistors, inductors, capacitors, resistors, diodes.  You have inspired me to design a box for it.  Nice work.
comments.author: wimberleytech

comments.text: Be sure to check the existing boxes, there seems to be several for all GM328 models I know of. I didn't like the tendency of most enclosures to cover parts of the board, which results in cumbersome usage of the zif lever or probe screws.
comments.author: wimberleytech

comments.text: Wow, there are lots of boxes for these, but I did not see my model.  Close but just different enough.  Part of the fun is the design anyway!!  I agree with you on the design.  No reason to put a pretty front on it.  Basically just a box to keep the 9V from bouncing around.
